objinfo.objsize: ranging between 16.6 x 11.0 cm. and 13.6 x 9.8 cm.
objinfo.numberleaves: 15Plates 1, 2, and 27 were printed recto only; all other plates were printed recto/verso, beginning with Plates 3/4 as the first pair.
objinfo.medium: relief and white-line etching with slight water-color washes on Plates 1-4Plates 17 and 25 include pen and ink overwriting on a few letters.
objinfo.printingstyle: reliefSome of the plates may have been printed in folio format, possibly on conjugate leaves. The rebinding of 1977-1978 eliminated any evidence of conjugacy.
objinfo.inkcolor: shades of reddish-brown (Plates 1, 3, 6, 8, 9, 12, 14, 15, 18, 19, 23-26), yellow ochre (Plates 2, 4, 5, 7, 22, 27), raw umber (Plates 10, 11), olive green (Plates 13, 17, 21), and green (Plates 16, 20).The shades of these colors vary a good deal, in part due to the thickness of the inking. The reddish-brown shades vary the most; they may be combinations of burnt umber and burnt sienna inks. Plate 26 may have been printed with a mixture of olive green and burnt umber inks.
objinfo.binding: modern calfBound no later than 1834 in half red morocco over marbled boards; rebound in the winter of 1977-1978 with each leaf attached to a stub. Until its removal during the 1977-1978 rebinding, an impression of Blake's separate plate of 1793, *Our End is come*, was bound as a frontispiece. Blake may have added this plate, or it may have been added by an early owner prior to 1834.
objinfo.stabholes: originally stabbed through three holes, 7.7 cm. from the top and 3.2 cm. and 4.0 cm. apart, according to Bentley page 298.The inner margins of the leaves were trimmed during the 1977-1978 rebinding, thereby eliminating any evidence of stab holes.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The bottom two-thirds of the plate seems to be beneath the ground level of the natural world, which occupies the top one-third. Near the bottom of the plate, beneath the word "hell" (line 6), a nude couple, perhaps (though not distinctly) female (left) and male (right) respectively, kiss while embracing. They are probably intended to represent the "marriage" of "heaven" and "hell" (lines 2, 4, 6). The figure on the right, facing left with its body twisted forward, is stretched out horizontally on a cloud; the figure on the left, facing right but with the body seen from the behind, hovers above a burst of flames. Above them several other figures, including some couples, fly upward between the flames on the left and the clouds on the right. Above them in turn, at ground level, in a landscape of leafless arching trees whose roots are visible below ground, as if seen in cross-section, a couple strolls on the left and a single figure kneels beside what may be another figure lying on the ground. Birds fly in the sky at the top of the plate.

lg.l: Rintrah roars & shakes his fires in the burdend air;
Hungry clouds swag on the deep
Once meek, and in a perilous path,
The just man kept his course along
The vale of death.
Roses are planted where thorns grow,
And on the barren heath
Sing the honey bees.
Then the perilous path was planted;
And a river, and a spring
On every cliff and tomb;
And on the bleached bones
Red clay brought forth.
Till the villain left the paths of ease,
To walk in perilous paths, and drive
The just man into barren climes.
Now the sneaking serpent walks
In mild humility.
And the just man rages in the wilds
Where lions roam.
Rintrah roars & shakes his fires in the
burdend air;
Hungry clouds swag on the deep.

lg.l: As a new heaven is begun, and it is now thir-
-ty-three years since its advent: the Eternal Hell
revives. And lo! Swedenborg is the Angel sitting
at the tomb; his writings are the linen clothes folded
up. Now is the dominion of Edom, & the return of
Adam into Paradise; see Isaiah XXXIV & XXXV Chap:
Without Contraries is no progression. Attraction
and Repulsion, Reason and Energy, Love and
Hate, are necessary to Human existence.
From these contraries spring what the religious call
Good & Evil. Good is the passive that obeys Reason
Evil is the active springing from Energy.
Good is Heaven. Evil is Hell,

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design repeats the strong left-right divisions of the lower title page and the lower design on Plate 3, but now with a landscape divided between water and fire rather than clouds and fire. On the left, running or flying over water, with a sun behind, is a nude figure of indeterminate sex holding a child. One of the color prints of this subject is inscribed by Blake "The Good & Evil Angels" (Butlin nos. 323-24).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Numerous interlinear designs ornament the plate. A heraldic vignette announces "The voice of the Devil" (lines 1-2): three angels blow their trumpets on either side of these two lines. To the left of the text, two of the angels—one gowned, the other nude—face up and left; to the right of the text, the third angel, also gowned, mirrors its companions, facing up and right. Beside the angel on the right, a vine, perhaps with one or two leaves and with at least one loop, rises from the first letter of "been" in line three. A bird flies to the right of the vine. Three leaf-like flags extend from the "d" of "sacred" and the "h" of "have" in line 3. These flags may represent the musical notes of the trumpeters. Below the bird, at the end of line 4, two figures, a gowned female and a child, reach out to each other, nearly touching hands. Further down, to the right of line 6, a small figure, its body and arms horizontal, flees from a recumbent figure on a leaf. Next to the words "the Soul" in line 9 are eight figures in sundry positions: the first of these—its body horizontal—flies toward two huddled figures. The figure facing right crouches or squats, reaching an arm out to its companion. The other figure sits facing left with hunched shoulders. They are followed by two hand-holding figures who hover above a streamer extending from the "M" of "Man" in line 10. Next to this pair, three figures huddle together on some vegetation consisting of leaves and/or vines. Following the word "Energies" in line 11 are four figures and two animals: the first animal, perhaps a horse, kicks up its back heels. Next to it stand two children holding hands, followed by another hand-holding pair, a child and an adult. The latter extends his left arm horizontally, perhaps pointing to the ox which grazes nearby on a bit of tableland. An ornamental ribbon, most likely vegetative in nature, closes the vignette. Further down the plate, a leaf grows from the "B" of "But" in line 12; this motif continues in the following line, where a leaf ornament introduces the text, and a leaf-like serif extends from the "l" of "Soul," closing line 13. A branch with spiky leaves grows from the "e" of "age" in line 16. Following it, an amorphous, horizontal figure hovers above two wispy lines, suggesting cirrus-like clouds or vines. The figure raises its arm, seemingly in an effort to make contact with the adjacent figure, who prepares to leave its vegetative bed. To the right, a man walks a small dog on a leash. An indistinct shape, perhaps a child, is stationed nearby. Headed in its direction, a lumbering figure, bearded or blindfolded, walks (runs?) in a contorted position, viz., bending forward from the waist with one arm outstretched in front of him. Mimicking his general posture, a shadow or an anthropomorphic tree arches to the left. Near the margin between lines 17 and 18, a small figure is supported by a cane. Six figures observe a seventh figure one line down. With legs slightly apart and arms raised, it appears to address its audience from behind a stump, staff, or walking stick. To its back is either a disproportionally large branch with a leaf, or else the fallen branch of a tree. Concluding the procession, two horses, the second of which is indicated merely by some faint profile lines, pull a figure in a cart.

lg.l: All Bibles or sacred codes. have been
the causes of the following Errors.
1. That Man has two real existing princi-
-ples Viz: a Body & a Soul.
2. That Energy. calld Evil. is alone from the
Body. & that Reason. calld Good. is alone from
the Soul.
3. That God will torment Man in Eternity
for following his Energies.
But the following Contraries to these are True
1 Man has no Body distinct from his Soul
for that calld Body is a portion of Soul discernd
by the five Senses, the chief inlets of Soul in this
age
2. Energy is the only life and is from the Body
and Reason is the bound or outward circumference
of Energy.
3 Energy is Eternal Delight

illustration.illusobjdesc: The nude male with outspread limbs, falling into flames with his sword, robe, chariot, cannonball (or sun), and horse, may represent "the Devils account" of the war in heaven: that "the Messiah fell. & formed a heaven of what he stole from the Abyss" (Plate 5, lines 15-16; Plate 6, line 2), though several other identifications are possible.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male with arms raised vertically and legs spread falls headfirst into flames. His fingers are spread apart. He may represent Christ, as "the Messiah" who "fell. & formed a heaven of what he stole from the Abyss" (Plate 5, lines 15-16; Plate 6, line 2).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The balance of the interlinear designs appear in the right and top margins of the plate. Flanking "Proverbs of Hell" (line 5) are two vignettes. To the left of the inscription, beneath a tree with long, drooping branches, a figure bends forward from the waist. In its hand is an implement of some kind, usually identified as a stick or dibble. To the right of "Hell" (line 5), a nearly erect serpent faces three figures, an adult and two children, all of whom have extended arms. Behind the third figure are sloping lines that may represent the side of a hill. Further down, in the right margin, a nude male runs right, his arm extended in front of him and one leg extended behind him. The edge of a cliff(?) looms to his right. In its hand the figure holds an implement, which is sometimes identified, with reference to the first proverb, as a stick or dibble for planting seeds.

The sloping lines to the right of the second child at the end of line 5 may represent the side of a hill or cliff.

lg.l: -roding fires he wrote the following sentence now per-
-cieved by the minds of men, & read by them on earth.
How do you know but ev'ry Bird that cuts the airy way,
Is an immense world of delight, clos'd by your senses five?
In seed time learn, in harvest teach, in winter enjoy.
Drive your cart and your plow over the bones of the dead.
The road of excess leads to the palace of wisdom.
Prudence is a rich ugly old maid courted by Incapacity.
He who desires but acts not, breeds pestilence.
The cut worm forgives the plow.
Dip him in the river who loves water.
A fool sees not the same tree that a wise man sees.
He whose face gives no light, shall never become a star.
Eternity is in love with the productions of time.
The busy bee has no time for sorrow.
The hours of folly are measur'd by the clock, but of wis-
-dom: no clock can measure.
All wholsom food is caught without a net or a trap.
Bring out number weight & measure in a year of dearth
No bird soars too high. if he soars with his own wings.
A dead body. revenges not injuries.
The most sublime act is to set another before you.
If the fool would persist in his folly he would become
Folly is the cloke of knavery.wise
Shame is Prides cloke.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vegetative motifs flank the plate's first line, "Proverbs of Hell": to the left of the words is an oak branch with five leaves and three acorns; following "Hell" (line 1), a many-looped tendril of a grapevine with a single leaf attached at the end extends to the right margin. The grapevine motif is reproduced elsewhere, and various leaves, buds, serpentine vines and/or flowers adorn the plate passim. Dangling from the end of line 4 is a cluster of grapes. Further down, in the right margin, a flock of birds soars on extended wings. A detached vine or branch, possibly with leaves, appears in the general space occupied by the birds, coinciding with one of their wings. Line 15 is teeming with small-scale designs: An eagle, lion, two figures, and some grazing sheep appear in close proximity to one another. Below, next to "rod" in line 18, a small figure, perhaps a child, peers up at a vaguely anthropomorphic tree. Following "fruits" in line 22 is a fruit- or blossom-bearing branch. To the right, numerous birds fly above a picturesque seascape, complete with boats or ships, and a tree grows from the side of a cliff overlooking the water. Two lines down, a coiled snake faces a leaping stag. A (grape?) vine with three leaves follows line 29.

lg.l: Prisons are built with stones of Law, Brothels with
bricks of Religion.
The pride of the peacock is the glory of God.
The lust of the goat is the bounty of God.
The wrath of the lion is the wisdom of God.
The nakedness of woman is the work of God.
Excess of sorrow laughs. Excess of joy weeps.
The roaring of lions, the howling of wolves, the raging
of the stormy sea, and the destructive sword, are
portions of eternity too great for the eye of man.
The fox condemns the trap, not himself.
Joys impregnate, Sorrows bring forth.
Let man wear the fell of the lion. woman the fleece of
the sheep.
The bird a nest. the spider a web, man friendship.
The selfish smiling fool. & the sullen frowning fool. shall
be both thought wise. that they may be a rod.
What is now proved was once, only imagin'd.
The rat, the mouse. the fox, the rabbet; watch the roots,
the lion. the tyger. the horse. the elephant, watch
the fruits,
The cistern contains; the fountain overflows
One thought, fills immensity.
Always be ready to speak your mind, and a base man
will avoid you.
Every thing possible to be believ'd is an image of truth.
The eagle never lost so much time. as when he submit-
-ted to learn of the crow.

lg.l: The fox provides for himself, but God provides for the lion.
Think in the morning. Act in the noon, Eat in the even-
-ing, Sleep in the night,
He who has sufferd you to impose on him knows you.
As the plow follows words, so God rewards prayers.
The tygers of wrath are wiser than the horses of in-
Expect poison from the standing water. -struction
You never know what is enough unless you know what is
more than enough.
Listen to the fools reproach! it is a kingly title!
The eyes of fire. the nostrils of air, the mouth of water,
the beard of earth.
The weak in courage is strong in cunning.
The apple tree never asks the beech how he shall grow,
nor the lion, the horse, how he shall take his prey.
The thankful reciever bears a plentiful harvest.
If others had not been foolish. we should be so.
The soul of sweet delight. can never be defil'd,
When thou seest an Eagle. thou seest a portion of Ge-
-nius. lift up thy head!
As the catterpiller chooses the fairest leaves to lay
her eggs on. so the priest lays his curse on
the fairest joys.
To create a little flower is the labour of ages.
Damn, braces: Bless relaxes.
The best wine is the oldest. the best water the newest.
Prayers plow not! Praises reap not!
Joys laugh not! Sorrows weep not!

lg.l: The ancient Poets animated all sensible objects
with Gods or Geniuses, calling them by the names and
adorning them with the properties of woods, rivers,
mountains, lakes, cities, nations, and whatever their
enlarged & numerous senses could percieve.
And particularly they studied the genius of each
city & country. placing it under its mental deity.
Till a system was formed, which some took ad-
vantage of & enslav'd the vulgar by attempting to
realize or abstract the mental deities from their
objects; thus began Priesthood.
Choosing forms of worship from poetic tales.
And at length they pronouncd that the Gods
had orderd such things.
Thus men forgot that All deities reside
in the human breast.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A male body, nude, arms at his sides, extends horizontally across the plate. The arrangement of the body suggests that he is dead. Hovering in flames over him is a nude(?), long- haired female figure with her arms raised horizontally. She is at right angles to the male with her head toward the viewer. At least twice Blake color printed the plate, with its text masked (Butlin nos. 260.5, 261.3). His inscription for one of these, "a Flaming Sword / Revolving every way" (E673, K 261), relates the design to the so-called covering cherub, or guardian angel, whom God posted to keep humanity away from the Tree of Life after the expulsion from Eden. The top (rotating) figure in the design would then seem to be a personification of the sword-as-angel who is keeping the dead figure below away from the Tree of Life.

lg.l: The ancient tradition that the world will be con-
sumed in fire at the end of six thousand years
is true, as I have heard from Hell.
For the cherub with his flaming sword is
hereby commanded to leave his guard at tree of
life, and when he does, the whole creation will
be consumed, and appear infinite. and holy
whereas it now appears finite & corrupt.
This will come to pass by an improvement of
sensual enjoyment.
But first the notion that man has a body
distinct from his soul, is to be expunged; this
I shall do, by printing in the infernal method, by
corrosives, which in Hell are salutary and me-
-dicinal, melting apparent surfaces away, and
displaying the infinite which was hid,
If the doors of perception were cleansed
every thing would appear to man as it is, in-
-finite.
For man has closed himself up, till he sees
all things thro' narrow chinks of his cavern.

lg.l: I was in a Printing house in Hell & saw the
method in which knowledge is transmitted from gene-
-ration to generation.
In the first chamber was a Dragon-Man, clear-
ing away the rubbish from a caves mouth; within, a
number of Dragons were hollowing the cave,
In the second chamber was a Viper folding round
the rock & the cave, and others adorning it with gold
silver and precious stones.
In the third chamber was an Eagle with wings
and feathers of air, he caused the inside of the cave
to be infinite. around were numbers of Eagle like
men, who built palaces in the immense cliffs.
In the fourth chamber were Lions of flaming fire
raging around & melting the metals into living fluids.
In the fifth chamber were Unnam'd forms, which
cast the metals into the expanse.
There they were reciev'd by Men who occupied
the sixth chamber, and took the forms of books &
were arranged in libraries.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The first lines on this plate—"The Giants who formed this world into its sensual existence and now seem to live in it in chains" (lines 1-3)—seem to describe the design, which depicts five gowned human figures sitting in severely contracted positions, all crowded into a dark stone chamber, prison, or cavern. The heads of all except the bearded central figure, who looks out toward the viewer, are down and turned toward the center. Though the limbs of the figures are drawn tightly together as if chained, no chains are in evidence—in line with the sentiment of the text that the giants only "seem" (line 2) to live in chains.

component.illusobjdesc: Five seated figures sit in a dark chamber, prison, or cave, probably built or cut from stone. The wall of this chamber is clearly visible behind the figures; the leftmost section appears cracked or broken.

The gowned figure on the far left sits near or possibly against a wall, facing toward the center, in a severely contracted position with the visible leg drawn up and head down. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 1-2).

The gowned figure second from the left sits with back against the wall in a severely contracted position with legs drawn up, head down but twisted toward the center, and right foot exposed, crossed in front of his or her left leg. The old, gowned male figure in the center, the only one of the five looking forward, sits with his back against the wall in a severely contracted position, legs drawn up and crossed, right foot exposed. In other copies, his arms are raised horizontally to embrace contiguous figures, but his arms are not pictured in this copy. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 1-2). The design, however, closely resembles Blake's several illustrations of the Ugolino episode in Dante's Divine Comedy, and thus this central figure is compositionally related to (albeit not directly identifiable as) Count Ugolino surrounded by his sons in prison.

The gowned figure fourth from the left sits with his right side against the wall, facing the center in a severely contracted position with his one visible leg drawn up and his head down. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 1-2).

objnote.p: At the bottom of the plate, in the waves under the leviathan, Blake wrote in white-line etching: "Opposition is True Friendship." Color printing obscured these words completely in Copies E and F, and watercolor finishing made them barely visible in the other colored copies, A, C, D, G-I.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the waves of a tumultuous sea, Leviathan appears as a coiled, scaly serpent with its head raised vertically, mouth open, teeth visible, tongue extended. In this copy, the final word of the inscription—"Opposition is True Friendship"—is illegible.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A bearded nude male, looking out at the viewer with an expression of apprehension and dismay, crawls on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks on the floor of a dark forest. The points of a crown can be seen on his head. This is apparently Nebuchadnezzar (not mentioned in the text), king of Babylon, enslaver of the Israelites, whose fall and exile are described in the apocalyptic Book of Daniel: "he was driven from men, and did eat grass as oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, till his hairs were grown like eagles' feathers, and his nails like birds' claws" (4:33). Beneath him, as much a caption to the design as a final line of text, is a Blakean proverb: "One Law for the Lion & Ox is Oppression" (line 11).
